context.text: In response to concerns about the integrity of the integrated circuit (IC) supply-chain, researchers have proposed numerous design obfuscation and locking techniques to protect hardware intellectual property blocks (IPs) [1]–[4][10].
Fabrics include embedded field programmable gate arrays (eFPGAs) [4], [6], coarse-grained reconfigurable architectures [12], and transistor fabrics [13].

Prior work has begun to explore these challenges by selecting functionality to redact from high-level (C-based) designs to maximize a security metric until hitting an area overhead threshold [6] or by choosing a single part of a design-at the register transfer level (RTL)-which guides the generation of an eFPGA fabric [4].
As with many security solutions, there is a trade-off between security and other design factors, such as area and timing [4]–[6].

Thus far, prior work has suggested eFPGAs for feasibly redacting an individual IP [4], [6]; however, given the nascent state of eFPGA-based redaction, we need more insights into the practical implications of using this IP protection approach so as to help designers make better redaction decisions.

Hence, eFPGA-based redaction is a potential panacea for reverse-engineering attacks; the regular structure of an eFPGA, avoids apparent structural biases while appearing to pose a challenge to attackers by introducing a large key-space (i.e., configuration bitstream) [4], [6].
“Designer-directed” redaction at the register transfer level using a custom fabric generation flow [4] produces a fabric for parts of the design the designer intuits as “security critical”.
As argued in prior work, the ability to create custom, small, fabrics can provide a better fit for redaction compared with off-the-shelf eFPGA IP [4].
Typically, designers redact a module after designing them [1], [4], which points towards hand-crafted modules in the IP as the starting point for potential redaction targets.
In contrast to related work [4], we treat the eFPGA fabric as a macro.
The alternative approach is to find a fabric size that matches the requirements of the “designer-directed” redaction choice [4].
Previous work has suggested that large FPGA bitstream lengths make SAT-based attacks impractical [6] and the results in Mohan et al.’ s evaluation appear to support this claim [4].
We consider an attack model favoring an attacker with access to a fully-scanned and unlocked design (i.e., an oracle) in addition to the netlist of the IP; this is typical from prior work [4].
In this section, we explore the security compromise when an attacker can recover a part of bitstream through a side-channel, replicating and extending the study in prior related work [4].

context.text: Spectrum sensing based on cognitive radio (CR) [1] is a promising solution to mitigate spectrum scarceness and spectrum underutilization by providing secondary access to idle primary spectrum bands.
It is a consequence of the fixed spectrum access policy [1] in actual use that gives access rights only to incumbents or primary users (PUs).

The problem is that these silent periods, which the literature shows to be frequent [1], leave vacant primary spectrum bands that secondary users (SUs) could use for other services and then mitigate underutilization.
In this new concept of spectrum access, SUs can opportunistically use primary portions of the spectrum if they find idle bands [1].

In this case, cooperating CRs in different geographical locations cooperate for more accurate decisions and surpass problems like shadowing, multipath fading, hidden primary terminals, or a combination of these phenomena [1].
Cooperative spectrum sensing may be centralized, distributed, or relay-assisted [1].

The FC, or each CR, achieves occupation decisions by implementing some statistical test, for example, matched-filter detection [4], energy detection [1], eigenvalue detection [5], or power spectral density (PSD) detection [6], [7].
Existing tests are known as non-blind [4], semi-blind [1], [5], or blind [5]-[7].

The FC achieves a final cooperative decision via the K-out-of-U rule [1], where K is the number of received ℋ1 decisions, and U is the total number of received decisions, i.e., the number of cooperating CRs.

Inspired by Frame Attention Networks (FAN) [14], which use attention weights to adaptively aggregate frame features, we decided to apply this mechanism to the feature vectors extracted by our EfficientNet model.
We will use the approach from frame attention networks [14], but we concatenate the frame features with the vector \$\overline{\mathbf{f}}\$.
For the recurrent neural network (RNN) models we randomly sample K consecutive frames and for the attention models, we borrow the frame sampling technique from [14].

Moreover, we support the superiority of attention-based learning over classification of mean frame [14]: the proposed implementation with the self-attention kernel is better than the baseline of classifying mean features with an SVM for both feature extractors.

Unlike the method proposed for FAN [14], where a frame was chosen from each of the K segments of a fixed size, we randomly sample K indexes from the input sequence, order them, and use the frames at these indexes.
We try sampling \$K=4\$ video frames using the technique from FAN [14] and using our proposed method (additionally passing the output of a statistical function to the network).
